item.title: Get Up To 18 Steam Games For As Low As $2.85 Each With Fanatical's Latest Bundle
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/get-up-to-18-steam-games-for-as-low-as-2-85-each-with-fanaticals-latest-bundle/1100-6531270/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Fanatical's Platinum Collection for May 2025 is now live, giving you a chance to pick up a bundle of PC games for as little as $2.85 each. You’ll get to build your own bundle by picking from a catalog of 18 titles, and the more you pick the more you’ll save. As a bonus, Fanatical will toss in a 5% off voucher for your next purchase. All games are offered as official Steam keys.

Cashing in on the offer is simple. Buy three or more games and they’ll cost $3.33 each, five or more for $3.00 each, or seven or more for $2.85 each. Prices will automatically adjust as you add more to your cart. There's no limit to how many you can add, and if you pick all 18, you'll pay just $51.30, which is a huge savings compared to the full bundle's $385 value.

As for the games available, The Forgotten City is one of the most compelling options. Released in 2021, the story-rich RPG has you rewinding time and attempting to figure out who destroyed an ancient city in the Roman Empire. Combat is one way to get your answers, but it’s often a better choice to charm, bribe, or interrogate your subjects. There’s no one way to navigate its challenges, making it excellent for multiple playthroughs.

Faith: The Unholy Trinity has earned Overwhelming Positive reviews on Steam, and it’s an easy recommendation as part of this bundle. With minimalist, retro graphics and a chilling story about demonic possession, it’s a great addition to any Steam library. Inspired by classic 8-bit games and the Satanic Panic of the 1980s, horror fans will find much to love about this unsettling adventure.

Other notable games include the roguelike boomershooter Ziggurat 2, the puzzle-platformer Deliver Us Mars, and the hilarious Yellow Taxi Goes Vroom. You could also check out Teslagrad Remastered and Teslagrad 2 with the Double Pack. The metroidvanias earned impressive reviews, thanks to vibrant graphics, heaps of unlockable skills, and surprisingly nuanced storylines. You'll find the full list of games available in Fanatical's May 2025 Platinum Collection outlined below and on the bundle Fanatical store page.

Platinum Collection (May 2025)

  • 63 Days
  • Aaero Complete Collection
  • Beyond Galaxyland
  • Deliver Us Mars
  • Desecrators
  • Faith: The Unholy Trinity
  • Hammerwatch Anniversary Edition & Hammerwatch II Double Pack
  • Lego Bricktales
  • Megaloot
  • New Star GP
  • Revenge of the Mage
  • Teslagrad Remastered & Teslagrad 2 Double Pack
  • The Foretold: Westmark Legacy
  • The Forgotten City
  • The Haunting of Joni Evers
  • Yellow Taxi Goes Vroom
  • Zero Protocol
  • Ziggurat 2

If you're looking for more savings, plenty of other bundles are available at Fanatical right now, including one that lets you snag a bunch of Bethesda games for $3 a piece. This includes Morrowind: GOTY Edition, Oblivion: GOTY Edition, and The Elder Scrolls Online--so if you're seeking an affordable alternative to Oblivion Remastered, this is definitely worth a closer look.

Disclosure: GameSpot and Fanatical are both owned by Fandom.

item.title: Halo Infinite Is Adding One Of Halo's Most Absurd And Incredible-Looking Guns To Date
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/halo-infinite-is-adding-one-of-halos-most-absurd-and-incredible-looking-guns-to-date/1100-6531297/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Microsoft has announced the next big update for Halo Infinite, and it introduces one of the more absurd and over-the-top weapons we've ever seen in Halo's history.

Say hello to the Mutilator, a new brute force weapon featuring a double-barrel shotgun with a Gravity Hammer attached to the end of it. The gun shoots one shell at a time or players can leverage the alt-fire option to shoot two rounds at once. As for the Gravity Hammer element of the gun, Microsoft said, "If there's anything left to devastate, the hammer should finish the job." You can see the new weapon in action in this Halo Infinite video, beginning at 46:50. It looks pretty devastating.

Microsoft created a dedicated mode to highlight the Mutilator, and it's called Mutilator Madness. It's a variant of the Juggernaut mode where a team of players square off against one super-powerful player.

Additionally, Microsoft is adding the Mutilator to regular Halo Infinite maps as a power weapon. Players can also use the weapon in custom matches and in Forge mode.

The Mutilator is coming to Halo Infinite on May 6 as part of the game's upcoming Operation: Last Stand update. The update also incudes a 20-tier free Operation Pass that allows players to unlock a variety of new cosmetics, while a paid 50-tier Premium Operation Pass will be available with even more content.

The Weapons Bench is getting updated, too, allowing players to apply weapon coatings, emblems, charms, and death effects to a variety of weapons. What's more, the Last Stand update brings back bouncing bullets so that projectiles from the S7 sniper rifle and the Flexfire sniper rifle will ricochet off hard surfaces, making the battlefield even more dangerous.

Additionally, the Last Stand update has nerfed the Banshee vehicle by raising the cooldown time for its fuel rod cannon and slowing down the velocity of its projectiles. "We hope these nudges will ensure a more balanced experience for all players. Ramming speed remains unchanged," Microsoft said.

Beyond ongoing updates for Halo Infinite, Microsoft is developing all-new Halo games using the Unreal Engine 5. It's still early days, however, and no new Halo games have been official announced as of yet.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: TMNT: Splintered Fate Collector's Edition Is Packaged In A Pizza Box
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/teenage-mutant-ninja-turtles-splintered-fate-collectors-deluxe-edition-amazon-preorder/1100-6531228/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Splintered Fate is getting a pair of physical editions on August 26: a $40 Deluxe Edition that comes with foil trading cards and a $100 Collector's Edition with a pizza box storage case loaded with cool extras. Preorders for both physical editions are available now at Amazon for PS5, PS4, Nintendo Switch, and Xbox.

TMNT: Splintered Fate originally released as an Apple Arcade exclusive in May 2023 before being ported to PC and Switch last summer. PlayStation and Xbox editions will be available digitally on May 20 and June 24, respectively. The Deluxe and Collector's Editions will bring Splintered Fate to physical format for the first time.

TMNT: Splintered Fate - Deluxe Edition

$40 | Releases August 26

Available for PS5, PS4, Switch, and Xbox, the Deluxe Edition includes the base game plus a bunch of extras. For one, you’ll get a physical pack of 10 foil trading cards featuring familiar faces like Leonardo, Donatello, Raphael, and Michelangelo. It also comes bundled with the Casey Jones DLC that adds the hockey-stick-wielding vigilante as a playable character, along with new enemies, bosses, and other additional content.

The Deluxe Edition will get you access to a future, currently unannounced DLC pack. Considering this version of the game is only $40 (compared to $30 for the base game), that’s a pretty impressive list of additional goodies.

TMNT: Splintered Fate - Pipin' Hot Collector's Edition

$100 | Releases August 26

Splintered Fate's Pipin' Hot Collector's Edition includes a bunch of additional extras. Considering its $100 price, this is one of the most jam-packed collector's editions we've seen in quite some time. The Pipin' Hot Collector's Edition is packaged in a slipcased pizza box. Here's everything you get:

  • Pizza Box storage case with slipcase
  • Mutant Ooze Green Tabletop RPG Dice
  • NYC Sewer Manhole Cover Dice Box
  • 50-page Art Book & Retro Manual
  • Foil Trading Card Pack (10 Cards)
  • Double-sided Metallic Coin
  • Splintered Fate Comic Book by IDW Publishing
  • 2 Exclusive Posters of Turtles & Casey Jones
  • Physical copy of TMNT: Splintered Fate
  • Casey Jones & The Junkyard Jam expansion

The Collector's Edition is available to preorder on PS5, PS4, Nintendo Switch, and Xbox for $100 at Amazon.

Our Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Splintered Fate review gave the side-scrolling a brawler a solid 7/10, praising it for fast roguelite action and fun cooperative gameplay modes. Since then, the game has been patched and updated, and the new physical release will enjoy all those improvements right out of the box.

TMNT has seen a bunch of cool merch released over the years, so if you’re looking to add some more Ninja Turtles flair to your home. If you're into classic board games and card games, you can grab TMNT-themed versions of Hungry Hungry Hippos and UNO, while anyone looking to enjoy the mutant quartet's adventures can grab the IDW Comics Collection Volume 1 for $24.55 (was $40) or the entire 1987 animated series on DVD for $26.59 (was $34). We've compiled a list of more TMNT comics, figures, and other collectibles below.

TMNT Collectibles and Merch

  • Hungry Hungry Hippos: TMNT Edition -- $25
  • The Last Ronin (Comic) -- $16.77 ($30)
  • The Last Ronin Funko Pop 4-Pack -- $60
  • TMNT 1987: The Complete Classic Series Collection (DVD) -- $26.59 ($34)
  • TMNT: The IDW Collection Volume 1 (Comic) -- $24.55 ($40)
  • Tubbz Donatello Rubber Duck -- $20
  • Turtle Power Ceramic Camper Mug -- $12
  • UNO: TMNT Edition -- $7

item.title: Game Pass Just Added Another Call Of Duty Game
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/game-pass-just-added-another-call-of-duty-game/1100-6531295/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

It's a big day in the world of Xbox Game Pass, as Microsoft has added another Call of Duty game to the subscription service. Activision's Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2 (the 2022 game) joined the Game Pass catalog, and it includes the full experience covering single-player and multiplayer.

MW2 is the third Call of Duty game that Game Pass subscribers can play via the subscription service. It joins Black Ops 6 and Modern Warfare 3. The battle royale title Call of Duty: Warzone is a free game that anyone can play--including Game Pass members--though it's not strictly a Game Pass title.

Modern Warfare 2 is playable on Game Pass via PC and Xbox.

Modern Warfare 2 was developed by Infinity Ward and is a sequel to the 2019 Modern Warfare reboot. Modern Warfare 3, developed by Sledgehammer Games and released in 2023, continued the story. According to Deadline, plans are underway for a fourth game in the reboot series.

After Microsoft acquired Activision Blizzard, many wondered if Microsoft would add older Call of Duty games to the Game Pass catalog, but as of yet, that hasn't happened.

Modern Warfare 2 isn't the only new introduction to Game Pass this week, as Ubisoft's Anno 1800 also recently arrived. The next release is Dredge on May 6. Despite the calendar rolling over to May 2025, Microsoft has yet to officially announce this month's full set of arrivals and removals, but the "leaving soon" page has already revealed some of the games leaving in the first half of May 2025.

Activision is expected to release a new Call of Duty game later this year, and it's rumored to be a Black Ops 2 sequel that could feature the return of a fan-favorite Zombies map.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Like A Dragon: Pirate Yakuza In Hawaii Collector’s Edition Is 50% Off
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/like-a-dragon-pirate-yakuza-in-hawaii-collectors-edition-is-50-off/1100-6531287/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii launched in February, earning positive reviews from critics. If you haven’t yet had a chance to check out the latest adventure or want to pick up a premium edition of the game with some cool collectibles, you can pick up Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii - Collector’s Edition on Xbox Series X for just $65.13 (was $130) as part of Amazon’s Gaming Week Sale that runs until May 4. This is the lowest price ever for the premium bundle and the first big discount the game has seen since launch.

Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii - Collector’s Edition

$65.13 ($130)

Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii Collector's Edition includes the base game and a long list of extras. Here’s a look at what you’ll find inside:

  • Legendary Pirate Crew DLC
  • Legendary Outfit DLC
  • Ship Customization DLC
  • Extra Karaoke & CD DLC
  • 6-inch Majima Acrylic Standee
  • Pirate Flag (12x18 inches)
  • Eye Patch
  • Treasure Coin Pin

With this discount, the Collector's Edition is only slightly more expensive than the standard edition on Xbox, making this offer hard to pass up. We’re expecting the limited-time deal to disappear on May 4, so cash in on the discount while you still can.

While the Xbox Series X version of Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii Collector's Edition is getting the biggest discount, you can also get the PS5 version for $117 (was $13), which still saves you a few dollars. And if you're looking to pick up the game as cheap as possible, you can grab the standard edition on Xbox Series X for $50 or on PS5 for $52 (both normally $60).

Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii deals

  • Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii Collector's Edition (Xbox Series X) -- $65.13 ($130)
  • Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii Collector's Edition (PS5) -- $117 ($130)
  • Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii (Xbox Series X) -- $50 ($60)
  • Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii (PS5) -- $52 ($60)

Our Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii review gave it a 7/10, praising its fast-paced combat, intriguing substories, and a satisfying final chapter.

“Like a Dragon: Pirate Yakuza in Hawaii is a solid spin-off, putting fan-favorite Goro Majima front and center with a suitably eccentric diversion into buccaneering piracy,” wrote critic Richard Wakeling. “The story doesn't pick up until an excellent final chapter, and it's disappointing that the narrative doesn't delve into Majima's complex personality, but this is still a thoroughly entertaining adventure on the high seas. It's quite unlike anything else in the long-running series, and even if it falters more often than usual, it's still essential for anyone who's previously called Kamurocho home.”

This isn’t the only premium edition discounted for Gaming Week. From Paradise Killer and Farming Simulator 25: Collector’s Edition to Ys Memoire: The Oath in Felghana and Darksiders 2, there are plenty of other bundles to explore. Many of these come with physical goodies, like the Pacific Drive: Deluxe Edition that comes with art prints, figures, and more, while others, like Star Wars Outlaws: Gold Edition, are bundled with DLC and bonus digital content. Check the list below for some of best deals on premium edition games discounted at Amazon--just remember these deals are only available through May, unless the sell out before then.

Premium Edition Video Game Deals

  • Darksiders 2: Deathinitive Edition (Xbox) -- $15 ($30)
  • Farming Simulator 25: Collector’s Edition (PC) -- $61.74 ($70)
  • Pacific Drive: Deluxe Edition (PS5) -- $30 ($40)
  • Paradise Killer: Collector’s Edition (Xbox) -- $46 ($90)
  • Potionomics: Masterwork Edition Limited Box Set (PS5, Switch, Xbox) -- $30 ($50)
  • Star Wars Outlaws: Gold Edition (Xbox) -- $30.84 ($110)
  • Trails through Daybreak 2 Deluxe Edition (PS5) -- $48 ($60)
  • Trinity Trigger: Day 1 Edition (PS5) -- $32.23 ($40)
  • Ys Memoire: The Oath in Felghana - D1 Refined Edition (Switch, PS5) -- $40 ($50)

item.title: Official Mario Kart Racing Wheels Get Steep Discounts At Amazon
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/official-mario-kart-racing-wheels-get-steep-discounts-at-amazon/1100-6531293/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Amazon is offering rare discounts on both of the officially licensed Mario Kart Racing Wheels for Nintendo Switch. Manufactured by frequent Nintendo accessory collaborator Hori, both wheels come with pedals and sport wired USB connections. Hori's Mario Kart Pro Deluxe Racing Wheel is discounted to only $77, down from $110. For younger racers, the better option might be the Mario Kart Pro Mini Racing Wheel for $54.52 (was $70).

Are these racing wheels compatible with Nintendo Switch 2?

While we haven't been able to 100% confirm support for Switch 2, Nintendo has stated that the upcoming console is backward compatible with many original Switch accessories. The Switch 2 Dock has two USB-A ports, so you should be able to use Hori's wheels to play Mario Kart World. Wired and Bluetooth Switch controllers are supposed to work just fine on Switch 2, and this should especially be true when dealing with officially licensed accessories like Hori's Mario Kart wheels.

We have reached out to Hori to confirm Switch 2 compatibility and will update this story if we hear back. Just know that there is a chance neither wheel will work on Switch 2. We'd be very surprised, but until we test it for ourselves or receive official confirmation, we can't be fully sure about any potentially backward compatible accessory.

It's also worth noting that Nintendo is releasing Joy-Con 2 wheel attachments alongside the Switch 2 and Mario Kart World on June 5. You'll be able to slot a Joy-Con 2 Controller in the wheel and play Mario Kart with motion controls. You can preorder the Joy-Con 2 Wheel Set for $25 at Walmart and other major retailers.

Hori Mario Kart Racing Wheel Pro Deluxe

$77 (was $110)

The Pro Deluxe model is a full-sized steering wheel with a dark red and black color scheme. It has textured grips, a sturdy base, a pair of pedals, and conveniently placed inputs located in the general area where your hands naturally rest. The ZR and ZL triggers are on the rounded part of the wheel, while the face buttons, D-pad, and various menu inputs run across the middle. Beyond the larger size and more premium feel, the biggest additional perk is the inclusion of removable paddles. The paddles, along with the ZR and ZL trigger placement, allow you to play Mario Kart and other racing games without needing to alter your hand position to press buttons.

Hori Mario Kart Racing Wheel Pro Mini

$54.52 (was $70)

The Pro Mini's color scheme is based on the shades of red and blue found on Mario's iconic outfit. Like the larger Pro Deluxe, it has a Mario logo in the center and various buttons around it, including a D-pad, four face buttons, and menu buttons. The four triggers/bumpers are also located in the center as yellow buttons. The Pro Mini doesn't have the textured wheel cover or detachable paddles found on the pricier option, but you'll still get a pair of peddles for accelerating and braking.

Mario Kart World is the first open-world game in series history and the biggest launch game for Switch 2. It's available to preorder for $80 at multiple retailers, but you won't need to buy it separately if you manage to secure a preorder for the Mario Kart World Switch 2 Bundle. Unfortunately, Switch 2 preorders sold out fast when they opened on April 24, and it's unclear if and when restocks will happen before the console arrives next month.

Preorders are still available for many of the first-party and officially licensed Switch 2 launch accessories.

item.title: Valve's Deadlock Has A Super-Secret Invite-Only Alpha Different From The Known Invite-Only Alpha
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/valves-deadlock-has-a-super-secret-invite-only-alpha-different-from-the-known-invite-only-alpha/1100-6531294/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Deadlock--the MOBA that Valve famously did not acknowledge after months of leaked footage, only to confirm its existence last summer--has been slowly inviting more and more players to its ongoing closed alpha test. However, it now seems as if there's an even more hidden alpha test, with even more limited invitations, after a streamer accidentally spilled the beans.

YouTube streamer Deathy was livestreaming Deadlock on his YouTube channel, when he seems to have booted up the wrong version of the game. Instead of the alpha test viewers were used to, instead the game loaded up additional characters--a roster of 40 available characters as opposed to the standard alpha's 30 playable heroes--as well as updated designs for some of those 30 heroes.

Some of the characters not found in the usual alpha test include a bellhop-themed character named Doorman, a reference to Mary Shelley's famous monster called Frank, and a character named Punkgoat whose art is a repeat of existing character Shiv. Deathy did end the stream and delete the archive when he realized his error, but screenshots still managed to hit the official Deadlock subreddit.

Deadlock is a 6v6 multiplayer shooter and MOBA--"multiplayer online battle arena"--game developed by Valve. The official Steam page says that the game is "in early development with lots of temporary art and experimental gameplay" and that "access is currently limited to friend invite via playtesters."

Jason Fanelli on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Devolver Re-Commits To Releasing A Game On The Same Day As GTA 6 After Delay
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/devolver-re-commits-to-releasing-a-game-on-the-same-day-as-gta-6-after-delay/1100-6531291/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Grand Theft Auto VI has officially been delayed out of 2025, with Rockstar Games announcing the upcoming and highly anticipated game will be released on May 26, 2026. Devolver Digital, which back in March declared they would release a game on the same day as GTA 6 no matter the release date, has re-committed to the bit--though we still don't know what game that will be of if this is all one big joke.

After Rockstar announced the delay, Devolver Digital posted on its X account acknowledging both the delay and its dedication to directly competing with Rockstar on launch day. "You can't escape us," the post reads. "May 26, 2026 it is, then." The specific game in question, if there is one, has not yet been confirmed by Devolver.

Despite the delay of whatever game the company plans to launch against GTA 6, Devolver Digital has a busy 2025 ahead of it. The publisher has already launched Look Outside, Gorn 2, and Shotgun Cop Man so far, with Baby Steps, Skate Story, and Possessors still scheduled between now and the end of the year.

Rockstar Games's parent company Take-Two Interactive, despite a slump in stock price after the announcement of the delay, also has a busy release schedule ahead of it. Civilization VII from Firaxis Games and WWE 2K25 from Visual Concepts have already seen release, with Mafia: The Old Country, Borderlands 4, and NBA 2K26 still to come before 2026 begins.

Jason Fanelli on Google+

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com
